DIVISION 2. - PLANNING COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Planning, ch. 58. 

Sec. 2-36. - Created. 
    Pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210, a planning commission for the town is hereby created. 
(Code 1992, § 2-6) 
State Law reference- Duty to create planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2210. 
Sec. 2-37. - Composition; appointment and term of members. 
    The planning commission shall consist of seven members appointed by the town council, all of whom shall be residents of the town, qualified by knowledge and experience to make decisions on questions of community growth and development; provided, however, that at least half of the members so appointed shall be owners of real property. One member of the commission may be a member of the town council. The term of such member shall be coextensive with the term of office to which he has been elected or appointed, unless the town council, at the first regular meeting each fiscal year, appoints others to serve as their representative. The remaining members of the commission shall serve for terms of four years each. If a member serving on the commission becomes a member of the town council, he shall be deemed to have vacated, and shall vacate, his term of office on the commission on the date of his taking office on the town council. 
(Code 1992, § 2-12) 
State Law reference- Appointment, terms, etc., of planning commission members, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 2-38. - Compensation. 
    All members of the planning commission shall receive the sum of $175.00 per month and shall be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred. 
(Code 1992, § 2-7) 
State Law reference- Authority to compensate members, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 2-39. - Officers. 
    The planning commission shall elect from the appointed members a chair and a vice-chair, whose terms shall be for one year. 
(Code 1992, § 2-9) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2217. 
Sec. 2-40. - Removal of members. 
    Any member of the planning commission may be removed from office for malfeasance in office. Notwithstanding the foregoing provision, a member of a local planning commission may be removed from office by the town council without limitation in the event that the commission member is absent from any three consecutive meetings of the commission, or is absent from any four meetings of the commission within any 12-month period, beginning upon the date of the planning commissioner's assumption of office. In either such event, a successor shall be appointed by the town council for the unexpired portion of the term of the member who has been removed. 
(Code 1992, § 2-10; Ord. No. 06-O-38, § 1, 10-10-2006) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 2-41. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Vacancies upon the planning commission, however caused, shall be filled by the town council for the unexpired term only. 
(Code 1992, § 2-11) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2212. 
Sec. 2-42. - Meetings. 
(a)  The planning commission shall fix the time for holding regular meetings, but it shall meet at least every two months. 
(b)  Special meetings of the planning commission may be called by the chair or by two members upon written request to the secretary. The secretary shall mail to all members, at least five days in advance of a special meeting, a written notice fixing the time and place of the meeting and the purpose thereof. 
(c)  Written notice of a special meeting is not required if the time of the special meeting has been fixed at a regular meeting, or if all members are present at the special meeting or file a written waiver of notice. 
(Code 1992, § 2-12) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2214. 
Sec. 2-43. - Quorum; majority vote. 
    A majority of the members of the planning commission shall constitute a quorum, and no action of the planning commission shall be valid unless authorized by a majority vote of those present and voting. 
(Code 1992, § 2-13) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2215. 
Sec. 2-44. - Functions, powers, duties and limitations. 
    The planning commission shall have the functions, powers and duties, and be subject to the limitations, which are prescribed by law. 
(Code 1992, § 2-14) 
State Law reference- General duties of planning commission, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2221. 
Secs. 2-45-2-65. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-66. - Town elections. 
(a)  The mayor and council members in office shall be elected on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November, beginning November 8, 2016, and in each subsequent even numbered year. The mayor and council members elected under this section shall enter upon the duties of their offices on the first day of January following the election. The mayor and council members shall continue to discharge the duties of their respective offices until their successors have qualified. 
(b)  The mayor and council members in office at the effective date of the ordinance from which this section derives (March 10, 2015) are continued in office for the term of office for which they were elected by operation of Code of Virginia, § 24.2-222.1 through December 31st of the year in which the term was to expire. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-10, § 1, 3-10-2015) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 15-O-10, § 2, adopted March 10, 2015, states that pursuant to Code of Virginia, § 24.2-222.1 the Town Council adopts the ordinance from which this section derives in conflict with section 3.1(b), Charter for the Town of Herndon (1968), as amended. By action of the General Assembly set out in Code of Virginia, § 24.2-222.1 with the adoption of the ordinance from which this section derives (which ordinance does not amend the Town's Charter) § 3.1(b) of the Charter, to the extent inconsistent with the ordinance from which this section derives, is rendered inoperable.

DIVISION 2. - TOWN MANAGER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Town manager, ch. 4. 

Sec. 2-81. - Compromise of small claims. 
(a)  On written approval of the town attorney, and after consideration of any available insurance coverage and the effect of the settlement on such coverage, the town manager is authorized and empowered to compromise any claim for damages or any suit or action brought against the town, where the claim or amount in controversy does not exceed $2,500.00. The town manager shall report to the mayor and the town council in writing any compromise effected under this authority. 
(b)  No such settlement shall constitute an admission of liability of the town. 
(c)  Each such settlement shall be supported by an instrument of full release on such form approved by the town attorney. 
(Code 1992, § 2-4) 
Charter reference- Actions against the town, § 7.2. 
Secs. 2-82-2-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - TOWN ATTORNEY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference- Town attorney, § 6.1. 

Sec. 2-96. - Legal proceedings. 
(a)  The town council approves the town attorney's institution and prosecution of all legal proceedings within the jurisdiction of the general district court that the town attorney deems necessary or proper to protect the interest of the town. 
(b)  Within seven days after the filing of such legal proceeding, the town attorney shall confidentially inform the town council of the institution and basis of the legal proceeding. Failure to comply with this subsection shall not affect the validity of any legal proceeding. 
(c)  This approval shall not be exclusive. The town council may separately act on approval of other legal proceedings. 
(Code 1992, § 2-3) 
Secs. 2-97-2-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL MATTERS[7] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the town or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the town or any evidence of the town's indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-11(2); any contract or obligation assumed by the town saved from repeal, § 1-11(3); any appropriation ordinance or any ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or for adopting an annual budget saved from repeal, § 1-11(6); any ordinance relating to local improvements and assessments therefor saved from repeal, § 1-11(7); any ordinance prescribing any rate, charge, deposit, fee or payment of money to the town saved from repeal, § 1-11(13); financial matters for Chestnut Grove Cemetery, § 22-41 et seq.; finance and taxation, ch. 30. 

Sec. 2-116. - Signing and sealing of deeds, contracts or other instruments. 
(a)  When the town council has authorized or accepted any deed, contract, or other instrument, and the execution of such instrument on behalf of the town requires the signature of the town to be made thereto, the mayor is authorized to sign and deliver such deed, contract, or other instrument on behalf of the town. 
(b)  The mayor is authorized to sign, deliver, or accept on behalf of the town, contracts where such action by law does not require approval by the town council. Where town council approval is so required, the mayor may only sign, deliver, or accept contracts on behalf of the town under authority that may be granted by the town council. 
(c)  The mayor is authorized to accept on behalf of the town deeds of real estate or other property interests conveyed to the town. 
(d)  As provided for in the charter for the Town of Herndon, during the absence or inability of the mayor to act, the vice-mayor shall possess the powers and discharge the duties of the mayor. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall affect the validity of contract or other instrument signed on behalf of the town by another authorized officer or employee of the town. In this regard the town manager or his designee is also authorized to sign and deliver for the town contracts of a value up to the small purchase limits as defined by section 30-311 or other ministerial undertakings of the town. 
(f)  Except as otherwise provided, in all cases when it is necessary by law or custom that the corporate seal of the town be affixed to any deed, contract, or other instrument, the town clerk is authorized to affix and attest the corporate seal of the town to such deed, contract, or other instrument. 
(g)  The mayor or town manager is authorized to sign and deliver leases to public bodies of space in the town hall. The leases shall be on the town's standard town hall lease form, have a term of five years or less, and afford the town the right to terminate the lease on no less than 90 days notice to the tenant. The town manager shall promptly report to the town council the granting of such a lease. 
(Code 1992, § 2-1; Ord. No. 01-O-27, § 1, 8-14-2001; Ord. No. 14-O-08, § 1, 3-11-2014; Ord. No. 16-O-35 , § 1, 12-13-2016) 
Charter reference- Powers and duties of mayor, § 3.6; town clerk, § 4.6. 
Sec. 2-117. - Checks returned to town for insufficient funds, no account or account closed; fee. 
    In accordance with the Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106, a fee in the amount of $50.00 shall be collected for the uttering, publishing or passing of any check or draft for payment of taxes or any other sums due the town, which is subsequently returned for insufficient funds, or because there is no account or the account has been closed. 
(Code 1992, § 2-2; Ord. No. 99-O-25, § 1(2-2), 7-13-1999; Ord. No. 04-O-31, § 1, 9-28-2004; Ord. No. 12-O-30, § 1, 11-27-2012) 
State Law reference- Fee for checks returned for insufficient funds, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-106. 
Sec. 2-118. - Payment of administrative costs. 
(a)  Except as provided below, the town may impose, upon each person chargeable with delinquent taxes or other delinquent charges, fees to cover the administrative costs to be paid to the town, and reasonable attorney's or collection agency's fees actually contracted for. The attorney's or collection agency's fees shall be 20 percent of the taxes or other charges so collected, excluding attorney's fees and administrative costs. The administrative costs shall be in addition to all penalties and interest, and shall be $30.00 for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to 30 or more days after notice of delinquent taxes or charges pursuant to Code of Virginia § 58.1-3919 but prior to the taking of any judgment with respect to such delinquent taxes or charges, and $35.00 for taxes or other charges collected subsequent to judgment. If the collection activity is to collect on a nuisance abatement lien, the fee for administrative costs to be paid to the town shall be $150.00 or 25 percent of the cost, whichever is less; however, in no event shall the fee be less than $25.00. 
(b)  The town shall not impose pursuant to this section, and this section does not apply to, any attorney's fees incurred in the town's filing of a complaint to sell real estate for the purpose of collecting delinquent taxes on such real estate or incurred in the town's collection of a lien to cover the town's costs for public nuisance abatement, weed or refuse control, or demolition or securing of an unsafe building. 
(Ord. No. 06-O-13, § 1, 3-28-2006) 
Sec. 2-119. - Additional assessment for electronic summons system. 
    There is assessed an additional sum of $5.00 as part of the costs in each criminal or traffic case in which defendant is charged with a violation of any statute or ordinance which violation arose within the town. The assessment shall be collected by the clerk of the court, remitted to the director of finance of the town, and held by the director of finance subject to disbursement by the town council to the local law-enforcement agency, the Herndon Police Department, solely to fund software, hardware, and associated equipment costs for the implementation and maintenance of an electronic summons system. The implementation of a town assessment shall replace any county fee that would otherwise apply. 
(Ord. No. 15-O-23, § 1, 8-11-2015)

Chapter 7 - ARTS DISTRICTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Introduction, intent and purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to create arts districts to attract new arts venues, support existing arts venues, and to encourage the expansion of existing venues in the town. These new, existing, and expanded businesses will increase the town's presence as a destination for arts activities, as well as the opportunities and benefits to town residents of arts offerings. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. 
    When used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed in this section: 
    Arts business is a business organization primarily engaged in arts instruction, media arts, performing arts, performing arts venue, visual arts creation or visual arts exhibit as defined herein. The term includes a museum and an arts office use. The business may engage in related, incidental retail sales. 
    Arts instruction teaches individuals skills in the performing arts, media arts, or visual arts through experience, study, performance and assessment, providing participatory learning and engaging students with skilled artists, teachers, and art. 
    Arts office is an office use associated with an arts business, such as performing arts events organization and promotion, or arts production. 
    Business shall have the same meaning as provided for in the business license tax in chapter 30 of this Code. 
    District means an arts district established pursuant to section 7-3 herein. 
    Existing business is an arts business which is physically located within the district prior to July 1, 2016. 
    Expanded business is an existing arts business which expands physically into new space within the district, to add at least 20 percent in gross square feet (enclosed or outdoors). 
    Media arts are film, video, audio and other forms of digital and Web-based media, including the production, exhibition, distribution, and preservation of the work. 
    Museum is a public or private nonprofit agency or institution organized on a permanent basis for essentially educational or aesthetic purposes which, using a professional staff, owns or uses tangible objects, cares for them, and exhibits them to the public in a physical setting on a regular basis. 
    New business is a new arts business physically located or locating in the district on or after July 1, 2016, which was not actively engaged in the conduct of trade or business in the district prior to the submission of a completed program qualification application. The new business shall generate a new use of the land or building, and not the continuation of an existing use. An existing business shall not qualify for incentives by reorganizing or changing its form in a manner that does not alter the basis of the business assets or result in a taxable event. 
    Performing arts are live music, theater, dance (excluding dance as exercise or fitness activity), and opera. 
    Performing arts venue is a place of indoor or outdoor public assembly for the presentation of the performing arts or media arts. 
    Qualified arts business is an existing or new arts business, in a district that has successfully completed the process described in section 7-6 herein. Businesses providing personal services or a business intended primarily for exercise or fitness are not eligible to be qualified arts businesses. 
    Visual arts are the arts of painting, photography, sculpture, printmaking, drawing, design, folk and traditional arts and craft. 
    Visual arts exhibit is a business or gallery which displays the visual arts to visitors. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 7-3. - Districts, establishment and boundaries. 
    There is hereby established a Downtown Herndon Arts District, consisting of all the area as shown on the map entitled "Herndon Arts District," dated January 12, 2016. The Herndon Arts District Map is hereby declared to be a part of this article and to have the same force and effect as if it was fully set forth and described herein. The Herndon Arts District Map shall be kept on file in the office of the community development department. 
    The town shall provide identifying signs or markings to delineate and identify any arts district created pursuant to this section. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
ARTICLE II. - ARTS DISTRICT INCENTIVES 

Sec. 7-4. - Waiver of fees. 
    A qualified arts business is afforded a 100 percent reduction of planning, zoning, and building permit application fees up to $2,000.00 total for any single project incurred in the initial establishment of the business, or expansion of the business, in an arts district. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 7-5. - Signage. 
    A qualified arts business is eligible for any provisions described for arts districts in section 78-508.7 of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
ARTICLE III. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 

Sec. 7-6. - Applications. 
(a)  The town manager or his designee will administer applications through the community development department. In determining eligibility for the incentives contained herein, the town manager or his designee shall be guided by this chapter. 
(b)  A new or existing arts business seeking to obtain the incentives of an arts district will meet with the community development department staff and submit a completed qualification application. The community development department shall perform an initial review of the business or project to determine if it qualifies for incentives and then forward the application and recommendation to the town manager or his designee. The town manager, or his designee acting as the agent of the town council, shall review the application and recommendation and make a final determination as to whether the business or project is qualified for the incentives herein. 
(c)  The application shall be signed by an official officer, member, agent or representative of the business authorized to sign on its behalf. 
(d)  If the town manager or his designee denies an application, he shall do so in writing stating the reasons therefore, and affording the applicant an opportunity to respond in writing or in person. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 7-7. - Compliance with article. 
    A qualified arts business that fails to pay in full any tax imposed by the town by the due date shall lose its incentive eligibility and its entitlement to any incentives afforded under this article until such taxes are paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Sec. 7-8. - Confidentiality. 
    To the extent permitted under the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, confidential business records shall be safeguarded from disclosure; provided, however, that as a condition of receiving the incentives provided herein, each applicant agrees to the release by the town of the monetary value of any incentive received. This agreement shall appear prominently upon the application for incentives and each signature upon an application shall bind the applicant to this condition. 
(Ord. No. 16-O-02, § 1, 1-12-2016) 
Chapter 10 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 26; fire prevention and protection, ch. 34; planning, ch. 58; solid waste, ch. 62; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 66; subdivisions of land, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 74; zoning, ch. 78. 
State Law reference- Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STANDARDS 

Sec. 10-21. - Adoption of statewide building code. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted and incorporated by reference the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code (2009 edition) adopted by order of the Virginia Board of Housing and Community Development, effective March 1, 2011, as amended, and as may be amended from time to time. This code contains provisions for new construction; property maintenance; dwellings, plumbing, mechanical and fire prevention regulations, among others. 
(b)  Enforcement of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code for construction and rehabilitation shall be the responsibility of the department of public works, acting through the building official. 
(c)  The town may inspect buildings or structures and enforce the provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code for existing buildings. The town council designates the department of public works to carry out such inspection and enforcement and designates the building official as the building maintenance official. The building maintenance official shall enjoy all power, authority, and prerogatives to enforce the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code as to existing buildings. 
(d)  Relative to enforcement of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code as to existing buildings, the town council requires compliance with any or all maintenance provisions of Part III (13 VAC 5-63-450 et seq.), the Virginia Maintenance Code, of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and assigns enforcement responsibility to the department of public works, operating through the building maintenance official. 
(e)  The town council authorizes the building official, or building maintenance official, or both, to issue or obtain a summons or warrant to enforce the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1992, § 5-1; Ord. No. 04-O-16, § 1, 4-27-2004; Ord. No. 11-O-31, § 1, 12-13-2011) 
State Law reference- Uniform Statewide Building Code, Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. 
Sec. 10-22. - Electrical, plumbing, gas, mechanical, and home improvement provisions. 
(a)  The electrical, plumbing, gas, mechanical and home improvement provisions of articles 1 and 2 of chapter 66, articles 1 and 2 of chapter 65 and articles 1 and 2 of chapter 64 of the code of the County of Fairfax, Virginia, 1976, as amended, are hereby adopted and incorporated into this section and such provisions shall apply and be enforceable within the town, except those provisions which are irreconcilable with other provisions of this chapter. Provisions which refer to the county or county officials and departments shall refer to the town or its officials and departments to the extent that the town has such officials or departments. 
(b)  Any person who is certified as a journeyman electrician, plumber, gasfitter or mechanical tradesman or as a master electrician, plumber, gasfitter or mechanical tradesman by the county or the commonwealth shall be considered certified as the same in the town. 
(c)  Any person who is licensed as either an electrical, plumbing, gas or mechanical contractor by the county or the commonwealth shall be considered licensed as the same in the town. It shall be unlawful for any person to work as either an electrical, plumbing, gasfitter or mechanical contractor within the town without having a current license issued in accordance with the chapters 66, 65 or 64 of the code of the County of Fairfax, Virginia, 1976, as amended. 
(d)  No person shall install or alter any electrical equipment as indicated in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, or make any addition or alteration in the arrangement of any electrical system in the town, or wire any building for the installation of any electrical lights, meters, heating devices or apparatus requiring the use of electrical current unless such person is considered certified as a master or journeyman electrician in the town pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that an apprentice or helper may do such work under the direct supervision of such a certified master or journeyman electrician on the job. 
(e)  No person shall install or alter any plumbing system or related appurtenances as indicated in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, or make any addition or alteration in the arrangement of any plumbing system in the town, or pipe any building for the installation of any appliance, meters, heating devices or apparatus requiring the use of potable water supply, sanitary or storm drainage unless such person is considered certified as a master or journeyman plumber in the town pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that an apprentice or helper may do such work under the direct supervision of such a certified master or journeyman plumber on the job. 
(f)  No person shall install or alter any gas system as indicated in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, or make any addition or alteration in the arrangement of any gas system in the town, or pipe any building for the installation of any appliance, meters, heating device or apparatus requiring the use of gas unless such person is considered certified as a master or journeyman gasfitter in the town pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that an apprentice or helper may do such work under the direct supervision of such a certified master or journeyman gasfitter on the job. 
(g)  No person shall install or alter any mechanical equipment or system as indicated in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, or make any addition or alteration in the arrangement of any mechanical system in the town, unless such person is considered certified as a master or journeyman mechanical tradesman in the town pursuant to the provisions of subsection (b) of this section; provided, however, that an apprentice or helper may do such work under the direct supervision of such a certified master or journeyman mechanical tradesman on the job. A mechanical tradesman shall only be authorized to perform the following activities as a result of such certification: 
(1)  Servicing or replacement of the various components of refrigeration, ventilation, air conditioning and heating equipment including, but not limited to, compressors, motors, controls, duct work and condensers; 
(2)  Servicing or replacement of the electrical components of refrigeration, ventilation, heating and air conditioning equipment; and 
(3)  Servicing or replacement of the gas control yoke on refrigeration and heating and air conditioning equipment. 
(h)  Any person who is licensed as a home improvement salesman by the county shall be considered licensed as the same by the town. It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a home improvement contractor or to act as a home improvement salesman for a home improvement contractor within the town without having a current license issued in accordance with chapter 61 of the code of the County of Fairfax, Virginia, 1976, as amended. 
(Code 1992, § 5-2) 
Sec. 10-23. - Violation of code provisions deemed a misdemeanor. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any owner or any other person, firm or corporation, on or after the effective date of any Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code (Code) provisions, to violate any such provisions. Any such violation shall be deemed a misdemeanor and any owner or any other person, firm or corporation convicted of such a violation shall be punished by a fine of not more than $2,500.00. In addition, each day the violation continues after conviction or the court-ordered abatement period has expired shall constitute a separate offense. If the violation remains uncorrected at the time of the conviction, the court shall order the violator to abate or remedy the violation in order to comply with the code. Except as otherwise provided by the court for good cause shown, any such violator shall abate or remedy the violation within six months of the date of conviction. Each day during which the violation continues after the court-ordered abatement period has ended shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person convicted of a second offense committed within less than five years after a first offense under Articles I through V of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $1,000.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a second offense committed within a period of five to ten years of a first offense under Articles I through V of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not less than $500.00 nor more than $2,500.00. Any person convicted of a third or subsequent offense involving the same property committed within ten years of an offense under articles I through V of this chapter after having been at least twice previously convicted shall be punished by confinement in jail for not more than ten days and a fine of not more than $2,500.00, either or both. No portion of the fine imposed for such third or subsequent offense committed within ten years of an offense under this chapter shall be suspended. 
(c)  The penalties for violations of article VI of this chapter shall be as set out in article VI. 
(Code 1992, § 5-3; Ord. No. 00-O-32, § 1, 10-10-2000) 
Secs. 10-24-10-45. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - BUILDING FEES 

Sec. 10-61. - Imposed. 
    The town council imposes fees in this division for building inspection and related functions. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4) 
Sec. 10-62. - Special inspections. 
    A fee shall be paid for each inspection involving an application for change in use or change in occupant or other special request which requires inspection by each or any of the building, electrical, plumbing and mechanical inspection branches and the fire marshal. If all disciplines are involved in inspections, the fee shall be $340.00. Should the inspections not involve all disciplines, a fee of $85.00 shall be paid for each discipline taking part in the inspection. These fees are not credited toward the cost of the permits. If the inspection is canceled in advance by the applicant, and not conducted, the fee is refundable upon application in writing to the building official within three months of the date of payment. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section A); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015)

    All permits necessary under the provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and the town property maintenance code shall be procured and paid for before initiation of work. The minimum fee for any permit shall be $85.00 with the exception of decks and additions less than 1,158 square feet. The minimum fee for decks and small additions less than 1,158 square feet shall be $125.00. All fees for permits issued on a minimum basis shall be paid in full at time of permit application. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015)

    The fee for the construction of a new building, addition or enlargement shall be based on the area (as determined by the exterior dimensions) of all floors, including basements or cellars, and horizontally projected roof areas as follows: for types of construction as defined in the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code.

Sec. 10-65. - Apartment building. 
    A separate building permit shall be issued for each apartment dwelling unit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-66. - Demolition. 
    The fee for a demolition permit shall be calculated at a rate of 2.42 percent of the estimated cost, with a minimum fee of $85.00. A bond in the amount of $1,000.00 shall be posted which shall be returned to the permit holder upon satisfactory completion of the work, leaving the premises free from all unsafe and hazardous conditions.

    A separate building permit shall be issued for each duplex dwelling unit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-68. - Home improvement. 
    For home improvement fees see applicable new building, addition or enlargement, or repair and alteration fees. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4 (section B)) 
Sec. 10-69. - Permit application; processing and plan examination. 
    To allow for permit application processing and plan examination if a building permit is not issued, the following fees shall be paid at the time of application for a permit: 
(1)  For a single-family residence, $135.00. 
(2)  For each type of house to be built in a cluster, complex or subdivision plan, $135.00. 
(3)  For all commercial work, apartment buildings, garden apartments, and high-rise residential buildings, $300.00. 
(4)  For plan revisions to approved plans, $40.00 per sheet. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-70. - Permit for quadplex. 
    A separate building permit shall be issued for each quadplex dwelling unit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-71. - Removal and relocation. 
    The fee for the permit for the removal of a building or structure from one lot to another or to a new location in the town shall be calculated at the rate of 2.42 percent of the cost of moving, plus the cost of the new foundations and all work necessary to place the building or structure in its completed condition in the new location. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 09-O-08, § 1, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-72. - Repairs and alterations. 
    The fee for repairs and alterations of any building or structure (other than residential which is calculated at the rate of 2.42 percent of the estimated cost of the work) where there is no addition or enlargement shall be calculated at the rate of 1.76 percent of the estimated cost of the work. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 09-O-08, § 1, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-73. - Single-family dwelling; issuance of permit. 
    A separate building permit shall be issued for each detached single-family dwelling unit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-74. - Special team instruction. 
    Special team instruction fees for the building portion only shall be $85.00. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-75. - Structure. 
    The fee for the erection or installation of structures other than buildings shall be calculated at the rate of 2.42 percent of the actual cost of the work. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 09-O-08, § 1, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-76. - Swimming pools. 
    The minimum fee for swimming pool inspection shall be $85.00. The maximum fee shall be $230.00 for private pools. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-77. - Tenant layouts. 
    Except for those tenant layouts shown on the originally approved plans for a building, separate building permits shall be required for each tenant layout, at a fee of 3.22 percent of the estimated cost of the work with a minimum construction cost of $15,000.00 used to determine the permit fee. If the permittee is able to prove through verifiable cost data that the cost of construction is less than $15,000.00, the permit fee will be prorated accordingly. In no case shall the permit fee be less than the minimum fee. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 09-O-08, § 1, 3-10-2009; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-78. - Townhouse. 
    A separate building permit shall be issued for each townhouse dwelling unit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-79. - Violation reinspection fee. 
    The violation reinspection fee shall be $72.00. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 10-O-17, § 1, 4-27-2010; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-80. - Fee for an inspection after regular working hours. 
    The fee for an inspection after regular working hours must be paid prior to inspection. A rate of $100.00 per hour, with a minimum of four hours, shall be paid. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 08-O-15, § 1, 5-27-2008; Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-81. - Shelters. 
    No fee shall be charged for building permits for radiation fallout or blast shelters constructed on lands occupied for residential purposes by not more than two families, for use as shelter only and constructed in accordance with one of the shelter types of designs approved by the office of civil defense mobilization of the United States government. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-82. - Emergency work. 
    For the purpose of facilitating emergency work when immediate necessity exists, construction, repairs and replacement to structures and buildings damaged by storms, fire, accident or any other emergency, where a delay would likely result in further damage or injury to persons or property, may be commenced immediately. The required building permit shall be applied for on the next regular working day after such work is commenced. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-83. - Fee payment credits. 
    All building fees paid at the time of permit application shall be credited toward the full cost of a building permit when the same is issued. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-84. - Nonpermitted work. 
    The fee for non-permitted work requiring an inspection prior to permit issuance shall be $72.00. Before a final inspection is released, the appropriate fee shall be paid for all work performed which is not authorized on the original permit. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B); Ord. No. 15-O-17, § 1, 5-26-2015) 
Sec. 10-85. - Permit suspension. 
    All permit fees will be forfeited on any permit invalidated because the authorized work is either not commenced within the valid life of the permit or if the authorized work is suspended or abandoned for a period of six months after the time of commencing work. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-86. - Refunds. 
(a)  In the case of a revocation of a permit or the abandonment or discontinuance of work, the permittee may, upon written request within the valid life of the permit, receive a refund for the amount of work the town has not performed. The amount of refund shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  All plan examination and permit processing fees shall be deducted from the original permit fee. 
(2)  All penalties that may have been imposed on the permit holder under the requirements of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and the Code of the town shall be deducted from the original permit fee. 
(3)  The volume of satisfactory work actually in place and approved by the town shall be determined, and a proportionate share shall be deducted from the original permit fee. 
(b)  Any excess fee for the uncompleted work shall be returned to the permit holder. No excess less than the minimum permit fee shall be refunded. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-87. - Solar energy. 
    No fee will be charged for permits to install solar energy equipment, although a permit is required for such installation. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Sec. 10-88. - Transfers. 
    Permit fees are not transferable. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section B)) 
Secs. 10-89-10-105. - Reserved.

    For an annual certificate of compliance, the owner shall pay to the town the annual fee for elevator mechanical inspection. The fee is payable before the inspection and includes the certificate which is awarded when the equipment is found safe and in conformity with applicable codes. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section D))

The required mechanical permit shall be applied for and fee paid on the next regular working day after such work is commenced. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section D))

(Code 1992, § 5-4(section D)) 
Sec. 10-130. - Permit renewal. 
    Upon written application of the permittee prior to the expiration of the original permit, the building official, or his designee, may renew the permit. The renewed permit shall be valid for 90 days from the expiration of the original permit. There will be no fees charged for permit renewals allowed by the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code and the Code of the town. 
(Code 1992, § 5-4(section D))

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 26. 
State Law reference- Authority for abating unsafe structures, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-906. 

Sec. 10-206. - Securing, removal or repair by owner. 
    The owners of property within the town shall at such times as the town council may prescribe, remove, repair or secure any building, wall or any other structure which the town council determines might endanger the public health or safety of other residents of the town. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(a)) 
Sec. 10-207. - Abatement procedure of town. 
    The town council, through its own agents or employees, may remove, repair or secure any building, wall or any other structure which might endanger the public health or safety of other residents of the town, wherein the owner and lienholder of such property, after reasonable notice and a reasonable time to do so, have failed to remove, repair or secure the building, wall or other structure. For the purposes of this section, repair may include maintenance work to the exterior of a building to prevent deterioration of the building or adjacent buildings. For purposes of this section, reasonable notice shall include a written notice mailed by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, sent to the last known address of the property owner and published in a newspaper having general circulation in the town in accordance with the applicable provisions of Code of Virginia, §§ 15.2-1426 and 15.2-1427. No action shall be taken by the town to remove, repair or secure any building, wall or other structure for at least 30 days following the later of the return of the receipt or newspaper publication. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(b)) 
Sec. 10-208. - Costs and expenses; collection. 
    If the town council, through its own agents or employees, removes, repairs or secures any building, wall or any other structure, after complying with the notice provisions of this article, the cost or expenses shall be chargeable to and paid by the owners of such property and may be collected by the town as taxes and levies are collected. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(c)) 
Sec. 10-209. - Liens. 
    Every charge authorized by this article with which the owner of any such property shall have been assessed and which remains unpaid shall constitute a lien against such property ranking on a parity with liens for unpaid local taxes and enforceable in the same manner as provided in Code of Virginia, §§ 58.1-3940 et seq., 58.1-3965 et seq. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(d)) 
Sec. 10-210. - Authority of public officials not limited by article provisions. 
    This article shall in no manner be construed as a limitation or restriction upon the authority of other public officials who are otherwise vested by law with the authority to require the repair, removal or securing of any building, wall or other structure within the town. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(e)) 
Sec. 10-211. - Administrative officer. 
    The director of public works of the town is vested with the authority and shall have the responsibility of administering and enforcing this article. 
(Code 1992, § 5-5(f)) 
Secs. 10-212-10-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SMOKE DETECTORS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 34. 
State Law reference- Smoke detectors, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-922. 

Sec. 10-231. - Where installed. 
    Smoke detectors shall be installed in the following structures: 
(1)  Multifamily residential buildings containing four or more dwelling units. 
(2)  Hotels or motels regularly used or offered for or intended to be used to provide overnight sleeping accommodations to one or more persons. 
(3)  Roominghouses, group homes, dormitories and other public lodgings regularly used or offered for or intended to be used to provide overnight sleeping accommodations. 
(Code 1992, § 5-7) 
State Law reference- Authority for requiring installation, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-922. 
Sec. 10-232. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete independent living facilities for one or more persons including permanent provisions of living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Owner means one or more persons, jointly or severally, in whom is vested: 
(1)  All or part of the legal title to the property; or 
(2)  All or part of the beneficial ownership and a right to present use and enjoyment of the premises, and the term includes a mortgagee in possession. 
    Smoke detectors means mechanical devices powered by batteries or alternating current capable of sensing visible or invisible products of combustion that sound an audible alarm. 
(Code 1992, § 5-8) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-233. - Installation requirements. 
(a)  The smoke detectors installed must be capable of sensing visible or invisible products of combustion, providing a suitable alarm. 
(b)  Appropriate permits as required must be secured for the installation of the smoke detectors powered by alternating current. No fee will be charged for the permit. 
(c)  The smoke detectors shall be installed in conformance with the provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1992, § 5-9) 
Sec. 10-234. - Responsibilities in multifamily residential buildings. 
(a)  The owner or agent of the owner of a multifamily residential building containing four or more dwelling units shall provide smoke detectors as required by section 10-233(c) in hallways, stairwells and other public or common areas and shall maintain them in good working order. 
(b)  The owner or agent of the owner of a dwelling unit which is rented or leased in a multifamily residential building containing four or more dwelling units, shall furnish the tenant at the beginning of each tenancy and at least annually thereafter, with written certification that all smoke detectors required are present, have been inspected and are in good working order. 
(c)  The tenant shall be responsible for reasonable care of the smoke detector in accordance with Code of Virginia, § 55-248.16, and for interim testing, repair and maintenance, and for providing written notice to the owner for repair of any malfunctioning smoke detector. The owner shall be obligated to provide and pay for service, repair or replacement of any malfunctioning smoke detector. Such service, repair or replacement must occur within five days of receipt of written notice from the tenant that a smoke detector is in need of service, repair or replacement. 
(d)  The owner or agent of the owner of a dwelling unit, which is rented or leased in a multifamily building containing four or more dwelling units, shall provide written notifications to the tenant of the responsibilities and duties imposed by subsection (c) of this section. 
(Code 1992, § 5-10) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-922. 
Sec. 10-235. - Enforcement. 
    The building official is authorized to administer and enforce this article. 
(Code 1992, § 5-11) 
Sec. 10-236. - Article not an exemption from compliance with code. 
    Nothing in this article shall excuse any owner for the required buildings from compliance with all other applicable provisions of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
(Code 1992, § 5-12) 
Secs. 10-237-10-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - NEIGHBORHOOD PRESERVATION[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Charter reference- Authority to adopt, § 2.3. 

DIVISION 1. - EXCESSIVE OCCUPANCY 

Sec. 10-256. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building code means the Uniform Statewide Building Code, and building regulations as defined by Code of Virginia, § 36-97, adopted and promulgated pursuant thereto. The Uniform Statewide Building Code is comprised of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, adopted by order of the state board of housing and community development, as amended, and building regulations as defined by Code of Virginia, § 36-97, as amended, adopted thereunder, pursuant to authority granted to the board of housing and community development and the town by Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. The building code may also be referred to as "building regulations." 
    Building regulations means, when not qualified as being defined by Code of Virginia, § 36-97, the same as building code. 
    Dwelling unit means a single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
    Excessive occupancy means the state of overcrowding of dwelling units as defined by the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code, as may be amended from time to time, and as defined in this chapter. 
    Interior public areas means the living room, dining room, halls or similar space of a dwelling unit. 
    Neighborhood blight means blighted or deteriorated areas, which are one or more areas (including slum areas) with one or more buildings or improvements which, by reason of dilapidation, obsolescence, overcrowding, faulty arrangement of design, lack of ventilation, light and sanitary facilities, excessive land coverage, deleterious land use or obsolete layout, or any combination of these or other factors, are detrimental to the safety, health, morals or welfare of the community comprising the town. 
    Occupant means any person living or sleeping in a building; or having possession of a space within a building. 
    Property maintenance code means the provisions of the International Property Maintenance Code (2003) of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code which is referred to as Part III of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code (2003), dealing with maintenance or use of existing buildings and structures, as adopted from time to time by the board of housing and community development, pursuant to authority granted to the board of housing and community development by Code of Virginia, § 36-97 et seq. 
    Residential rental building means any single-family detached, single-family attached, or multifamily dwelling unit or units, whether in condominium, cooperative, commercial or private ownership, which is the subject of a lease between an owner or owner's agent and a tenant. 
    Town manager means the town's town manager or designee. 
(Code 1992, § 5-17; Ord. No. 04-O-16, § 2, 4-27-2004; Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 2, 3-27-2007) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-257. - Prohibition of excessive occupancy. 
(a)  Occupancy of dwelling units shall be limited to the maximum number of persons allowed by the Virginia Maintenance Code, in order to discourage or eliminate neighborhood blight caused by excessive occupancy, as defined by the Virginia Maintenance Code. 
(b)  The Virginia Maintenance Code allows maximum occupancy of dwelling units as follows: 
(1)  Every room occupied for sleeping purposes by one occupant shall contain at least 70 square feet of floor area; and every room occupied for sleeping purposes by more than one person shall contain at least 50 square feet of floor area for each occupant thereof. Kitchens, nonhabitable spaces and interior public areas shall not be occupied for sleeping purposes. 
(2)  The expression of the rules of this section shall not exclude other occupancy limitations as set out in the Virginia Maintenance Code or in the zoning ordinance, Chapter 78, Herndon Town Code (2000), as amended. In case of conflict or overlap, the limitation more restricting occupancy shall apply. 
(c)  An owner of a dwelling unit that occupies or suffers the occupancy of a dwelling unit by a number of persons in excess of the maximum occupancy here prescribed shall forthwith lower the occupancy to a level consistent with the limits of this section. 
(d)  An occupant of a dwelling unit occupied by a number of persons in excess of the maximum occupancy prescribed shall forthwith lower the occupancy to a level consistent with the limits of this section. 
(e)  The town manager is authorized to investigate incidences of possible excessive occupancy in the town. In exercising the powers granted by this section, the town manager may inspect buildings according to the procedures set out in Code of Virginia, §§ 19.2-393-19.2-397 or 36-105(C)(3) (or some comparable, later provisions), with necessary changes, for administrative enforcement; or according to general law of this state for criminal enforcement. 
(f)  Upon the town manager's conclusion that there exists excessive occupancy of a dwelling unit, the town manager, on behalf of the town, may seek an injunction to limit, lower or control the number of persons who may reside in or occupy the dwelling unit. 
(g)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall constitute a class 3 misdemeanor. 
(Code 1992, § 5-18; Ord. No. 04-O-16, § 3, 4-27-2004; Ord. No. 11-O-31, § 2, 12-13-2011) 
State Law reference- Inspection warrants, Code of Virginia, §§ 19.2-393-19.2-397. 
Sec. 10-258. - Designation of areas subject to neighborhood blight. 
(a)  On application of any person aggrieved by the existence of conditions that might be or lead to neighborhood blight with respect to an area in the town; or on application authorized by official action of a homeowners' association, unit owners' association, or neighborhood association adversely affected by such conditions; or on application by the town council, the town council may designate an area of the town as subject to neighborhood blight. The town manager shall resolve in writing any question as to whether or not a citizen may be so aggrieved or such an entity may be so adversely affected. 
(b)  Prior to consideration of such designation, the town council shall refer the application to the planning commission and review any recommendation of the planning commission, determined after a public hearing. The planning commission shall act, if it does, within 90 days after town council's referral of the matter to the planning commission. 
(c)  The town council shall make any such designation by ordinance, adopted after one or more public hearings, in which the council must make, if it can, an affirmative finding of the need to protect the public health, welfare and safety of its citizens in the designation of the area as subject to neighborhood blight. 
(d)  A designation shall be effective for two years after it is made. After that term has ended, the designation (or extension thereof) shall automatically cease to exist, unless during the term (or extension thereof) the town council by ordinance, in which the finding described in subsection (c) of this section is made, extends the designation for an additional two-year term. The council may refer the extension of a designation to the planning commission for review and recommendation under subsection (b) of this section, with necessary changes. 
(e)  The town council by resolution may terminate any designation upon a finding that the conditions constituting neighborhood blight have been remedied or no longer exist. 
(Code 1992, § 5-19) 
Sec. 10-259. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 4, adopted March 27, 2007 repealed former section 10-259 in its entirety which pertained to residential rental unit inspections and derived from the Code of 1992, § 5-20. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL RENTAL INSPECTION PROGRAM 

Sec. 10-260. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this division: 
    Building department means department of public works, acting through the building official. 
    Dwelling unit means a building or structure or part thereof that is used for a home or residence by one or more persons who maintain a household. 
    Owner means the person shown on the current real estate assessment books or current real estate assessment records. 
    Residential rental dwelling unit means a dwelling unit that is leased or rented to one or more tenants. However, a dwelling unit occupied in part by the owner thereof shall not be construed to be a residential rental dwelling unit unless a tenant occupies a part of the dwelling unit which has its own cooking and sleeping areas, and a bathroom. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-261. - Inspection of rental dwelling units. 
    The town may inspect residential rental dwelling units for compliance with the Building Code and to promote safe, decent and sanitary housing for its citizens, in accordance with the following: 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (c), the dwelling units shall be located in a rental inspection district established by the town council in accordance with this section; and 
(b)  The rental inspection district is based upon a finding by the town council that (i) there is a need to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the occupants of dwelling units inside the designated rental inspection district; (ii) the residential rental dwelling units within the designated rental inspection district are either (1) blighted or in the process of deteriorating, or (2) the residential rental dwelling units are in the need of inspection by the building department to prevent deterioration, taking into account the number, age and condition of residential dwelling rental units inside the proposed rental inspection district; and (iii) the inspection of residential rental dwelling units inside the proposed rental inspection district is necessary to maintain safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for tenants and other residents living in the proposed rental inspection district. Nothing in this division shall be construed to authorize a town-wide rental inspection district. The town council shall limit the boundaries of the proposed rental inspection district to such areas of the town that meet the criteria set out in this section; or 
(c)  An individual residential rental dwelling unit outside of a designated rental inspection district is made subject to the rental inspection ordinance based upon a separate finding for each individual dwelling unit by the town council that (i) there is a need to protect the public health, welfare and safety of the occupants of that individual dwelling unit; (ii) the individual dwelling unit is either blighted or in the process of deteriorating; or (iii) there is evidence of violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for tenants living in such individual dwelling unit. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-262. - Notification to owners of dwelling units. 
(a)  Before adopting a rental inspection ordinance and establishing a rental inspection district or an amendment to either, the town council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed ordinance. Notice of the hearing shall be published once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper published or having general circulation in the town. 
(b)  Upon adoption by the town council of a rental inspection ordinance, the building department shall make reasonable efforts to notify owners of residential rental dwelling units in the designated rental inspection district, or their designated managing agents and shall notify owners or managing agents of any individual dwelling units subject to the rental inspection ordinance, not located in a rental inspection district. The notice shall advise of the adoption of such ordinance and provide information and an explanation of the rental inspection ordinance and the responsibilities of the owner thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-263. - Notification by owners of dwelling units to locality. 
(a)  The rental inspection ordinance may include a provision that requires the owners of dwelling units in a rental inspection district to notify the building department in writing if the dwelling unit of the owner is used for residential rental purposes. The building department shall develop a form for such purposes. The rental inspection ordinance shall not include a registration requirement or a fee of any kind associated with the written notification pursuant to this section. A rental inspection ordinance may not require that the written notification from the owner of a dwelling unit subject to a rental inspection ordinance be provided to the building department in less than 60 days after the adoption of a rental inspection ordinance. However, there shall be no penalty for the failure of an owner of a residential rental dwelling unit to comply with the notice requirements adopted under the provisions of this section, unless and until the building department provides personal or written notice to the property owner, as provided in this division. 
(b)  In any event, the sole penalty for the willful failure of an owner of a dwelling unit who is using the dwelling unit for residential rental purposes to comply with the written notification requirement shall be a civil penalty of up to $50.00, as determined by the building official, using the standards in this division. For purposes of this section, notice sent by regular first class mail to the last known address of the owner as shown on the current real estate tax assessment records shall be deemed compliance with this requirement. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-264. - Initial inspection of dwelling units when rental inspection district is established. 
    Upon establishment of a rental inspection district in accordance with this division, the building department may, in conjunction with the written notifications as provided for in section 10-263, proceed to inspect dwelling units in the designated rental inspection district to determine if the dwelling units are being used as a residential rental property and for compliance with the provisions of the Building Code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such property. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-265. - Provisions for initial and periodic inspections of multifamily dwelling units. 
    If a multifamily development has more than ten dwelling units, in the initial and periodic inspections, the building department shall inspect only a sampling of dwelling units, of not less than two and not more than ten percent of the dwelling units, of a multifamily development, which includes all of the multifamily buildings which are part of that multifamily development. In no event, however, shall the building department charge a fee authorized by this division for inspection of more than ten dwelling units. If the building department determines upon inspection of the sampling of dwelling units that there are violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such multifamily development, the building department may inspect as many dwelling units as necessary to enforce the Building Code, in which case, the fee shall be based upon a charge per dwelling unit inspected, as otherwise provided in section 10-269. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-266. - Follow-up inspections. 
    Upon the initial or periodic inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to a rental inspection ordinance, the building department has the authority under the building code to require the owner of the dwelling unit to submit to such follow-up inspections of the dwelling unit as the building department deems necessary, until such time as the dwelling unit is brought into compliance with the provisions of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-267. - Periodic inspections. 
    Except as provided in section 10-266, following the initial inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to a rental inspection ordinance, the building department may inspect any residential rental dwelling unit in a rental inspection district, that is not otherwise exempted in accordance with this section, no more than once each calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-268. - Exemptions from rental inspection ordinance. 
    Upon the initial or periodic inspection of a residential rental dwelling unit subject to a rental inspection ordinance for compliance with the building code, provided that there are no violations of the building code that affect the safe, decent and sanitary living conditions for the tenants of such residential rental dwelling unit, the building department shall provide, to the owner of such residential rental dwelling unit, an exemption from the rental inspection ordinance for a minimum of four years. Upon the sale of a residential rental dwelling unit, the building department may perform a periodic inspection as provided in section 10-267, subsequent to such sale. If a residential rental dwelling unit has been issued a certificate of occupancy within the last four years, an exemption shall be granted for a minimum period of four years from the date of the issuance of the certificate of occupancy by the building department. If the residential rental dwelling unit becomes in violation of the building code during the exemption period, the building department may revoke the exemption previously granted under this section. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-269. - Fees. 
    The following fees are established for enforcement of the Virginia Uniform Statewide Building Code. 
Fee Schedule 
Initial inspection, per dwelling unit ..... $70.00 
Follow up inspection, per dwelling unit ..... 30.00 
Periodic inspection, per dwelling unit ..... 60.00 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-270. - Relation to other laws. 
(a)  The provisions of this division section shall not in any way alter the rights and obligations of landlords and tenants pursuant to the applicable provisions of Chapter 13 (§ 55-217 et seq.) or Chapter 13.2 (§ 55-248.2 et seq.) of Title 55, Code of Virginia. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not alter the duties or responsibilities of the local building department under § 36-105, Code of Virginia to enforce the building code. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-271. - Penalty. 
    Unless otherwise provided in this division, penalties for violation of this section shall be the same as the penalties provided in the building code, in § 36-106, Virginia Code, incorporated by reference. 
(Ord. No. 07-O-13, § 3, 3-27-2007) 
Sec. 10-272. - Rental inspection districts established-Branch Drive, Park Avenue, and Waterford Park. 
(a)  Pursuant to this division, the town council by this section establishes and designates three respective rental inspection districts for the following three developments:

The building department shall develop a form for such purpose.

Chapter 11 - SHORT-TERM RENTAL REGISTRATION

Sec. 11-1. - Definitions.
As used in this section:

Director means the Director of Finance or his designee.

Operator means the proprietor of any dwelling, lodging or sleeping accommodation offered as a short-term rental, whether in the capacity of owner, lessee, sublessee, mortgagee in possession, licensee, or any other possessory capacity.

Short-term rental means the provision of a room or space that is suitable or is intended for occupancy for dwelling, sleeping, or lodging purposes, for a period of fewer than 30 consecutive days, in exchange for the charge for the occupancy.

( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Sec. 11-2. - Registration required.
(a)The owner or operator of any dwelling, lodging or sleeping accommodation who offers, for a charge, or rents such to persons for short term rental must register annually with the department of finance on the town's short-term rental registry.(b)The registration shall state the name, residence, business address of the owner and/or operator and the addresses of all properties within the town offered for short-term rental. There shall be no fee for such registration. After initial registration, registration shall be renewed by January 1 of each year.
( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Sec. 11-3. - Exceptions.
Any person who is (1) licensed by the real estate board or is a property owner who is represented by a real estate licensee; (2) registered pursuant to the Virginia Real Estate Time Share Act, Code of Virginia § 55-360 et seq., or (3) licensed with the department of health related to the provision of room or space for lodging shall present evidence of such other licensing or registering to the director and be exempt from registering under this chapter. Should such registration or licensing cease, the person shall forthwith register with the director on the town's short-term rental registry.

( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Sec. 11-4. - Failure to register, fine and penalty, appeal.
(a)Any owner and/or operator who is required to register under this chapter who fails to register within 30 days of offering a property for rent or renting said property shall be subject to a fine of $500.00. Unless and until the owner/operator pays the fine and registers the property, such person shall not continue to offer any property for short term rental.(b)Any owner or operator required to register under this chapter may be prohibited from offering a specific property in the town upon multiple violations on more than three occasions of applicable state and local laws, ordinances, and regulations, as they relate to short-term rental, including any applicable Town transient occupancy taxes or meals taxes.(c)A decision of the director under this section may be appealed to the town manager upon the filing within ten business days of the date of the notice of the action of the director.
( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Sec. 11-5. - Non-contravention.
Except as provided in this chapter, nothing herein shall be construed to prohibit, limit, or otherwise supersede existing local authority to regulate short-term residential rental of property through general land use and zoning authority. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to supersede or limit contracts or agreements between or among individuals or private entities related to the use of real property, including recorded declarations and covenants; the provisions of condominium instruments of a condominium created pursuant to the Condominium Act (section 55-79.39 et seq.) of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended; the cooperative instruments of a cooperative created pursuant to the Virginia Real Estate Cooperative Act (Section 55-424 et seq.) of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended; or any declaration of a property owners' association created pursuant to the Property Owners' Association Act (Section 55-508 et seq.) of the Code of Virginia, 1950, as amended.

( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Sec. 11-6. - Administration and enforcement.
It shall be the responsibility of the director to administer, interpret and enforce the provisions of this chapter. Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the director may enter into agreements, subject to local law, with computer platform hosts of short-term residential rentals, to facilitate the efficient collection of the transient lodging tax pursuant to this Code.

( Ord. No. 20-O-03 , § 1, 1-14-2020)

Chapter 14 - BUSINESSES[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AUTOMOBILE GRAVEYARDS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Motor vehicles and traffic, ch. 42. 
State Law reference- Authority of town to regulate automobile graveyards, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-903; regulations, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-348. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-21. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile graveyard means any lot or place which is exposed to the weather and upon which more than five motor vehicles of any kind, incapable of being operated, are placed, allowed to remain, or to be found. 
(Code 1992, § 13-53) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 33.1-348(b)(2). 
Sec. 14-22. - Restrictions on location. 
    No automobile graveyards shall be established in the town within 500 feet of any state highway and none within 1,000 feet of any primary highway, except on land which has been specifically designated therefor or zoned for industrial use and subject to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1992, § 13-54) 
Sec. 14-23. - Fence or hedge required. 
    Any person who on April 4, 1968, maintained an automobile graveyard, any part of which is within 500 feet of any state highway, prior to the granting of a certificate for the continued use of such graveyard, and upon being notified by the town council that the graveyard qualifies for a certificate, shall erect and thereafter maintain a fence or hedge around such automobile graveyard. Such fence or hedge shall be not less than six feet high and shall be of such height to sufficiently conceal the automobile graveyard from the view of a person standing at the same level as such graveyard. 
(Code 1992, § 13-55) 
Secs. 14-24-14-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE TO OPERATE 

Sec. 14-41. - Required. 
    An automobile graveyard established and operating in the town on April 4, 1968, shall secure from the town council a certificate approving the continued operation of such automobile graveyard or the establishment of a new one, as the case may be. 
(Code 1992, § 13-56) 
Sec. 14-42. - Application; fee. 
    Any person proposing to establish and operate an automobile graveyard shall file with the town treasurer an application upon a form provided by the town for the establishment and operation of an automobile graveyard and shall deposit therewith $10.00 to cover the cost and expense of a public hearing and other costs for processing such application. Such fee shall not be refunded. 
(Code 1992, § 13-57) 
Sec. 14-43. - Public hearing. 
(a)  Upon receiving an application for a certificate under this article, the town council shall fix a date for a public hearing upon the application. The time, date and place of hearing upon the application shall be advertised by publishing a notice once a week for two successive weeks in a newspaper having general circulation in the town, which date of public hearing shall be not less than ten days from, nor more than 15 days after, the date the notice was first published. 
(b)  At the hearing upon the pending application the town council shall take into consideration the nature and development of the surrounding property; its proximity to churches, schools, hospitals, public buildings or other public places; the effect it may have upon the health, safety and welfare of the general public; whether or not the proposed location is within a business or industrial zone of the town; whether or not adjoining property owners object to the location of the automobile graveyard; whether the continued operation or the establishment of a new automobile graveyard will decrease property values in the general area; and such other circumstances as the town council shall from time to time determine and establish as a basis for determining whether a certificate should be granted or refused. 
(Code 1992, § 13-58) 
Sec. 14-44. - Appeals from action of town council. 
    Any person aggrieved by the action taken by the town council pursuant to this article may, within 20 days from the date of the refusal or issuance of a certificate, appeal to the circuit court of the county. Such appeal shall be heard in the same manner as civil appeals, and the court may enter such order in relation to the action appealed from as the court may deem proper and equitable. 
(Code 1992, § 13-59) 
Sec. 14-45. - Records; inspection of premises. 
    Any person who shall be granted a certificate to establish or operate an automobile graveyard shall keep a daily record of all purchases made of automobiles or parts therefrom, and all sales of automobiles or parts, which shall be available for police inspection at any and all reasonable times. The premises upon which the automobile graveyard is operated shall be open for police inspection and examination at all times. 
(Code 1992, § 13-60) 
Secs. 14-46-14-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, CANVASSERS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 66. 
State Law reference- Authority of town to regulate or prohibit peddling, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-1114. 

Sec. 14-66. - Registration. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit orders for, peddle, vend or sell goods, wares or services, or to canvass on a door-to-door basis within the town boundaries without:
