(Code 1992, § 24-7) 
Sec. 38-78. - Storage of property; payment of fees and expenses in relation to storage of property. 
    The town manager or his duly authorized agent may, but is in no event required to, store in any commercial warehouse or garage in the town, or in or on any facility owned by the town, any property coming into the custody of the police department. Storage fees and other expenses incurred in relation to storage of property shall be paid by any person claiming and receiving such property as the owner or lienholder thereof or by any person reclaiming and receiving possession thereof. 
(Code 1992, § 24-8) 
Sec. 38-79. - Proof of entitlement to possession of property; release and indemnification. 
(a)  Any person claiming property or reclaiming possession thereof must submit proof, satisfactory to the chief of police or his duly authorized agent, to show that he is the true owner or lienholder of the property or the person who voluntarily submitted possession of the property to the police department. Any such person may be required, prior to the release of any property, to execute in favor of the town and its officials and employees a release from all future liability and an agreement to indemnify and hold harmless the town and its officials and employees from all liability resulting from release of the property. 
(b)  There shall be no liability on the town or on any official or employee of the town as a result of deterioration of property, or deterioration in the value thereof, after it comes into the possession of the police department. There shall be no liability on the town or on any official or employee of the town for releasing property to one not entitled to receive possession thereof, provided that the release of the property was not in bad faith. 
(Code 1992, § 24-9) 
Chapter 42 - MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Ordinances prescribing traffic regulations for specific streets, such as ordinances establishing speed limits, or designating one-way streets, no parking areas, truck routes, stop intersections, intersections where traffic is to be controlled by signals, etc., saved from repeal, § 1-11(10); automobile graveyards, § 14-21 et seq.; inoperable vehicles, § 26-306 et seq.; law enforcement, ch. 38; offenses, ch. 46; go-carts and similar vehicles in parks, § 50-25; traffic in parks, § 50-46 et seq.; vehicle parking after dark, § 50-107; streets, sidewalks and certain other public places, ch. 66; supplementary district regulations for vehicles, § 78-1371 et seq. 
State Law reference- Motor vehicles, Code of Virginia, title 46.2; general powers of town with respect to motor vehicles and traffic, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1300 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 42-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Words and phrases used and contained in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, except where the context clearly requires a different meaning. 
(b)  These terms shall convey these respective meanings. 
    Areas zoned for residential use. All areas of the town which have been zoned to a zoning classification which permits one or more residential dwelling units. The zoning boundaries shall be used in the enforcement of the requirements of this chapter. However, in any case in which a street serves as the boundary between an area zoned for residential use and an area zoned for another use, then the centerline of that street shall be considered as the boundary between the area zoned for residential use and the area zoned for another use. 
    Commercial vehicle. 
(1)  Any solid waste collection vehicle, tractor truck or tractor truck/semitrailer or tractor truck/trailer combination (or any part thereof), dump truck, concrete mixer truck, towing and recovery vehicle, box type truck, flatbed truck, or heavy construction equipment, whether located on private property or on a truck, trailer, or semitrailer; 
(2)  Any trailer, semitrailer, or other vehicle in which food or beverages are stored or sold; 
(3)  Any trailer or semitrailer used for transporting landscaping or lawn-care equipment whether or not such trailer or semitrailer is attached to another vehicle; 
(4)  Any taxicab; 
(5)  Any motor vehicle licensed by the Commonwealth for use as a common or contract carrier or as a limousine; 
(6)  Any truck with a registered gross weight, or gross vehicle weight rating as defined in § 46.2-341.4, Code of Virginia, of 10,000 or more pounds; 
(7)  Any other trailer or semitrailer used for commercial purposes; 
(8)  Any motor vehicle or vehicle not described above, used for commercial purposes, and bearing on its exterior a commercial sign; and 
(9)  Any pick-up truck, panel truck, or truck with attached, external ladder or equipment racks utilized for commercial purposes. 
    Highway. This term refers to public streets as defined in § 46.2-100, Va. Code. The Town Council may by ordinance specifically designate private streets as "highways" for the purpose of this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 13-1; Ord. No. 00-O-27, § 1, 1-9-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 42-2. - Chapter applicable to drivers of all vehicles regardless of ownership. 
    The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles, regardless of ownership, subject to such specific exceptions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 13-2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-801. 
Sec. 42-3. - Adoption of state law. 
(a)  Pursuant to Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1313 and 1-13.39:2, the provisions contained in Code of Virginia, title 46.2, and in Code of Virginia, § 18.2-266 et seq., including all procedural, substantive and penalty provisions relating to the operation of vehicles in this commonwealth are adopted, incorporated in this chapter by reference, made a part of this chapter as fully as if set forth in this section, and are made applicable within the town. The incorporation by reference of these statutes shall not apply to those provisions, the violation of which constitutes a felony, or those provisions which are expressly inapplicable to towns. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the town to violate or fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of Code of Virginia, title 46.2, and of Code of Virginia, § 18.2-266 et seq., which are adopted by this section. 
(c)  It is the town council's intent that this section incorporating by reference state statutes shall include future amendments to the state statutes. The incorporation by reference in this section of future amendments to such state statutes shall become effective upon the effective date of such statutes as state law. 
(Code 1992, § 13-3) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt state law, as amended, Code of Virginia, § 1-13.39.2; general powers of town with respect to motor vehicles and traffic, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-1300-46.2-1314; authority to adopt state law regarding motor vehicles, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1313. 
Sec. 42-4. - Compliance with chapter; penalty for violation of chapter. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse, fail or neglect to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter or any rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(b)  Whenever a penalty is provided in the Code of Virginia for the violation of any section of the Code of Virginia adopted by reference in section 42-3 of the Town Code, the penalty for a violation of section 42-3 shall be the same as the penalty provided by state statute for a like offense. Operation of any motor vehicle in excess of a maximum speed limit established for a highway in a residence district, when indicated by appropriately placed signs displaying the maximum speed limit and the additional penalty for violations, shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $200.00, in addition to other penalties provided by law. The appearance of the signs and the operation of this program with necessary changes shall meet the "policy and procedures" on this subject adopted from time to time by the commonwealth transportation board and any town policies and criteria that may be approved by ordinance or resolution from time to time by the town council. No such signage shall be placed except on order of the town council expressed by resolution adopted (if it is adopted) after a public hearing. 
(c)  Every person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, for which no other penalty is provided and which is not defined as a misdemeanor, shall be punished by a fine of not more than $200.00; provided, however, that in no event shall any penalty imposed for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or rule or regulation promulgated pursuant thereto, exceed the penalty prescribed by general law of the commonwealth for a like offense. 
(Code 1992, § 13-19; Ord. No. 00-O-28, § 1, 9-26-2000) 
State Law reference- Penalty for traffic infractions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-113; town not to impose a penalty for traffic violation which is greater than penalty imposed by state law for similar offense, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1300. 
Sec. 42-5. - Funeral processions. 
(a)  No operator of a vehicle shall drive between the vehicles, persons or animals comprising a funeral or other authorized procession, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. This subsection shall not apply to authorized emergency vehicles. 
(b)  Each driver in a funeral procession shall drive as near to the right-hand edge of the roadway as is practicable and shall follow the vehicle ahead as close as is practicable and safe. 
(c)  The police department of the town may provide for escort of funeral processions, in or near the town when equipment and personnel are not otherwise engaged in law enforcement activities. 
(Code 1992, § 13-7) 
State Law reference- Funerals, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-828. 
Sec. 42-6. - Unlawful riding. 
    No person shall ride any vehicle upon any portion thereof not designated or intended for the use of passengers. This section shall not apply to an employee engaged in the necessary discharge of a duty, or to persons riding within truck bodies in space intended for merchandise. 
(Code 1992, § 13-10) 
Sec. 42-7. - Operating motor vehicles/mopeds on property designated for use by pedestrians and/or nonmotor vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle or moped as defined by Code of Virginia, § 46.2-100, on any property open to the public that is designated to be used solely by pedestrians and/or nonmotor vehicles. 
(b)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to publicly owned vehicles when they are used in the performance of official duties or to utility vehicles used for the installation and/or maintenance of utilities located within the subject property. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $200.00. 
(Code 1992, § 13-20) 
Sec. 42-8. - Operator to give full time and attention to driving. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the highways of the town without giving his full time and attention to the operation of the vehicle. 
(Code 1992, § 13-21) 
State Law reference- Powers of local authorities generally, erection of signs and markers, maximum penalties, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1300; regulation of traffic, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2028. 
Sec. 42-9. - Vehicle to be kept under proper control. 
    No person shall operate a motor vehicle upon the highways of the town, failing to keep the vehicle under proper control at all times. 
(Code 1992, § 13-22) 
State Law reference- Powers of local authorities generally, erection of signs and markers, maximum penalties, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1300; regulation of traffic, Code of Virginia, § 15.2-2028. 
Sec. 42-10. - Civil penalty for certain driving offenses. 
(a)  A person convicted of violating any of the following provisions shall be liable to the town for restitution at the time of sentencing or in a separate civil action for restitution of reasonable expenses incurred by the town, when providing an appropriate emergency response to any accident or incident related to such violation: 
(1)  The provisions of §§ 18.2-51.4 or 18.2-266, Code of Virginia, or a similar ordinance, when such operation of a motor vehicle while so impaired is the proximate cause of the accident or incident; 
(2)  The provisions of Article 7 (§ 46.2-852 et seq.) of Chapter 8 of Title 46.2, Code of Virginia, relating to reckless driving, when such reckless driving is the proximate cause of the accident or incident; 
(3)  The provisions of Article 1 (§ 46.2-300 et seq.) of Chapter 3 of Title 46.2, Code of Virginia, relating to driving without a license or driving with a suspended or revoked license; and 
(4)  The provisions of § 46.2-894, Code of Virginia, relating to improperly leaving the scene of an accident. 
(b)  A person convicted of violating any of the above provisions shall at the time of sentencing or in a separate civil action, be liable to the town for restitution of reasonable expenses incurred by the town when issuing any related arrest warrant or summons. 
(c)  Personal liability under this section for reasonable expenses of an appropriate emergency response shall not exceed $1,000.00 in the aggregate for a particular accident, arrest or summons, or incident occurring in the town. In determining the "reasonable expenses," the town may bill a flat fee of $250.00; or the town may bill a minute-by-minute accounting of the actual costs incurred based on the current average per minute police response cost determined in writing by the town manager each July 1 and filed in the office of the town clerk. 
(d)  As used in this section, "appropriate emergency response" includes all costs of providing law-enforcement services. 
(e)  In any civil action brought under this section, the town must prove the personal liability for reasonable expenses of an appropriate emergency response by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(f)  The court may order as restitution the reasonable expenses incurred by the town for such responding law enforcement services. 
(g)  The provisions of this section shall not preempt or limit any remedy available to the commonwealth or to the town to recover the reasonable expenses of an emergency response to an accident or incident not involving impaired driving, operation of a vehicle or other conduct as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 03-O-37, § 1, 10-28-2003; Ord. No. 06-O-37, § 1, 10-10-2006; Ord. No. 09-O-32, § 1, 8-11-2009) 
Secs. 42-11-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 42-31-42-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION 

Sec. 42-46. - Contracts with private persons for removal of vehicles. 
(a)  In order to carry out the provisions of this chapter, and to provide for the safety and welfare of the motoring public, the town manager or the chief of police may enter into agreements with any person providing wrecker services for motor vehicles if such person meets the following requirements: 
(1)  Ability to respond promptly to police calls 24 hours a day; 
(2)  Adequate storage facilities should the storage facilities of the town be inadequate; 
(3)  Adequate wrecker equipment with experienced personnel and capability of maintaining a well-managed and efficient business operation; 
(4)  Adequate liability, theft and hazard insurance to cover motor vehicles which are towed and stored; 
(5)  Agreement as to a schedule of reasonable rates for wrecker and storage facilities, as determined from time to time by the town manager; and 
(6)  Such other requirements as the town manager or chief of police may prescribe which are consistent with or implement the purposes of this section. 
(b)  The chief of police shall maintain a current list of all persons with whom the town has entered into agreement. Whenever wrecking services are requested, the persons on such list and capable of providing the services required shall be dispatched on a rotating basis. If such person does not then have a wrecker available for prompt service, the next person on the list shall then be called, and this procedure shall be continued until wrecking services have been obtained. This procedure may be deviated from when unique circumstances require and when there will be no unreasonable discrimination of or against persons with whom the town has entered into agreement. 
(c)  Except where emergency circumstances otherwise require, nothing in this section shall be construed as interfering with the right of anyone to obtain wrecker or storage services of his own choice. 
(Code 1992, § 13-12) 
State Law reference- Authority to regulate towing services, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1217. 
Sec. 42-47. - Powers of town manager. 
(a)  The town manager may designate intersections at which vehicles shall come to a full stop or yield the right-of-way and may cause to be erected appropriate signs or markers at such intersections so that an ordinarily observant person will be aware of the existence of such designation. 
(b)  The town manager may classify vehicles with reference to parking and may designate the time, place and manner such vehicles may be allowed to park on town streets and parking lots, including areas or zones for the loading and unloading of passengers or freight, goods, wares and merchandise from vehicles, and may make and enforce such additional rules and regulations as parking conditions may require. When any parking regulation is established pursuant to this subsection, the town manager shall cause to be erected appropriate signs or markers so that an ordinarily observant person, who may be affected by such regulation, will be aware of such regulation. 
(c)  The town manager may cause appropriate signs and markings to be erected, placed and maintained, designating residence and business districts, railway crossings and such other signs and markings upon the sidewalks and streets as may be deemed necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(d)  When any regulation is made pursuant to this section and when appropriate signs or markers have been erected as required by this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to violate any such regulation. 
(Code 1992, § 13-13) 
State Law reference- Authority of town council to delegate right to designate stop and yield right-of-way intersections, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1301; authority to delegate right to promulgate parking regulations, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-1220. 
Secs. 42-48-42-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENFORCEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Enforcement of traffic, parking and other vehicle regulations, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936 et seq. 

Sec. 42-61. - Arrest for violations of chapter; release on summons and promise to appear; admitting to bail; violations. 
(a)  Whenever any person is detained by or in the custody of an arresting officer including an arrest on a warrant, arrest for a violation of any provision of this chapter punishable as a misdemeanor, the arresting officer shall, except as otherwise provided in section 42-62, take the name and address of such person and the license number of his motor vehicle and issue a summons or otherwise notify him in writing to appear at a time and place to be specified in such summons or notice. Such time shall be at least five days after such arrest, unless the person arrested shall demand an earlier hearing. Such person shall, if he so desires, have a right to an immediate hearing or a hearing within 24 hours at a convenient hour, and before a court having jurisdiction within the town. Upon the giving by such person of his written promise to appear at such time and place, the officer shall forthwith release him from custody. 
(b)  Any person refusing to give such written promise to appear shall be taken immediately by the arresting or other police officer before the nearest or most accessible judicial officer or other person qualified having jurisdiction under this chapter. 
(c)  Any person who willfully violates his written promise to appear, given in accordance with this section, shall be guilty of a class 1 misdemeanor and treated in accordance with the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-938. 
(d)  Any officer violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of misconduct in office and subject to removal therefrom upon complaint filed by any person in a court of competent jurisdiction. This section shall not be construed to limit the removal of a police officer for other misconduct in office. 
(Code 1992, § 13-15) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936. 
Sec. 42-62. - When arresting officer shall take person before judicial officer in lieu of issuing summons. 
    If any person is believed by the arresting officer to have committed a felony; believed by the arresting officer to be likely to disregard a summons issued under Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936; or refuses to give a written promise to appear under the provisions of Code of Virginia, § 46.2-936 or Code of Virginia, § 46.2-945, the arresting officer shall promptly take him before a magistrate or other issuing authority having jurisdiction to determine whether probable cause exists that such person is likely to disregard a summons. The magistrate or other authority may issue either a summons or warrant as he or she shall determine proper. 
(Code 1992, § 13-17) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-940. 
Sec. 42-63. - Enforcement of parking regulations. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the town police officers and any employee of the police department designated by the chief of police as a parking enforcement official to enforce the parking regulations of the town, and to submit to the director of finance or designee, a written report of each violation. 
(b)  The police officer or parking enforcement official making this report shall also attach a parking ticket to the vehicle in violation of the parking regulations indicating that, (i) such vehicle has been parked in a manner that fails to comply with the provisions of the parking regulations, (ii) notice is given to the violator to pay the appropriate sum according to the fine schedule as set forth in section 42-152, to the director of finance or his designee, within 30 days from the issued date, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays, and national holidays, (iii) if the violator does not pay or contest the violation within 30 days of the time appearing and provided for on such notice of parking violation, then a penalty of $25.00 shall be added to the sum owed to the town. The parking ticket shall provide that if the violator pays the appropriate fine set out in section 42-152 to the director of finance or designee within such time, no action shall be taken to prosecute him for the excessive or improper parking specified on such notice; otherwise, he will be in violation of this chapter and a magistrate summons will be issued in due course subjecting the violator to all the penalties provided in section 42-4. 
(c)  If the violator should contest any parking ticket, the contest shall be indicated in writing within the above 30-day period, on an appropriate form prepared by the director of finance or designee, and forwarded by the director of finance or designee to the Fairfax County general district court with a copy to the Herndon police department. 
(d)  When the violator ignores the parking ticket or fails to pay the corresponding fine, the director of finance or designee, not earlier than seven days after the expiration of the 30-day period provided for in subsection (b) of this section, may provide the violator a law enforcement notice as required by section 42-64. If the violator does not pay or otherwise resolve the issue within five days of receipt of the law enforcement notice, the director of finance or his designee may cause to be issued a magistrate summons for the parking violation and shall refer the magistrate summons and associated paperwork to the general district court for assignment of a trial date and for the prosecution of the offense. The director of finance or designee may also utilize any civil collection techniques provided by law for collection of debts due to the town. 
(e)  The director of finance or designee is authorized to levy and collect a late payment penalty of $25.00 per violation to defray administrative costs when a parking violation of this chapter occurs and the violator fails to pay the fine within the prescribed 30-day period. 
(f)  This section is intended to provide an aid to the strict enforcement of the parking regulations in this chapter without imposing an undue burden upon violators and shall be construed as a method of enforcement in addition to the other methods provided by law and in this chapter. 
(Code 1992, § 13-16; Ord. No. 99-O-31, § 2(13-16), 9-28-1999; Ord. No. 02-O-10, § 1, 2-26-2002; Ord. No. 17-O-17 , § 1, 8-8-2017; Ord. No. 17-O-21 , § 1, 10-10-2017) 
State Law reference- Enforcement provisions of parking ordinance and violations, Code of Virginia, §§ 46.2-941, 46.2-1225. 
Sec. 42-64. - Conditions precedent to issuance of a magistrate summons for violation of parking regulations. 
    Before any magistrate summons shall issue for the prosecution of a violation of any provisions of this Code or other regulations of the town regulating parking, the violator shall first be notified by mail at his or her last known address or at the address shown for such violator on the records of the department of motor vehicles, that he or she may pay the fine provided by law for such violation within five days of receipt of such notice, and the police officer or parking enforcement official issuing such magistrate summons shall be notified that the violator has failed to pay such fine within such time. The notice to the violator, required by the provisions of this section, shall be contained in an envelope bearing the words "law enforcement notice" stamped or printed on the face thereof in 14 point or larger type. 
(Code 1992, § 13-18; Ord. No. 99-O-31, § 4(13-18), 9-28-1999; Ord. No. 17-O-17 , § 1, 8-8-2017) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, Code of Virginia, § 46.2-941. 
Secs. 42-65-42-85. - Reserved.
